title: "What is the true nature of human consciousness according to Gurdjieff and Uspenskij?"
first_phrase: The last 200 tokens of this text talk about the human ego and its illusions. Gurdjieff, his students, Schwaller de Lubicz, and Uspenskij discuss the importance of understanding the reality of oneself and the world. According to them, the human being is a collection of small "me"s that change according to circumstances, and the ego is an illusion created by memories and projections. To understand reality, one must confront the net of dreams and elevate to a higher level of consciousness. Louis Cattiaux argues that this process involves realizing one's complete and absolute powerlessness. Only by confronting the truth about ourselves can we truly understand reality.

last_phrase: In order to truly understand oneself and attain higher levels of consciousness, it is necessary to observe and master one's automatic behavior and instincts. This process, as described by various philosophers and teachers throughout history including Gurdjeff, Meyrink, and Uspenskij, requires a practical approach of observing one's own behavior without interpretation. By doing so, an individual can gain a deeper understanding of themselves and their place in the world.
